content.text: To design and deliver a coherent, rigorous, and culturally responsive curriculum that integrates Cambridge International Education standards with Indonesian national requirements, ensuring students develop both global competencies and a strong Indonesian identity while meeting all regulatory obligations.

items.title: Standards-Based
points: Aligned to Cambridge learning objectives and Indonesian national curriculum standards
Clear learning outcomes for each subject and grade level
Assessment criteria are transparent and communicated to students

items.title: Coherent and Sequential
points: Logical progression from grade to grade (vertical alignment)

items.title: Culturally Responsive
points: Honors Indonesian values, history, and context
Prepares students as confident Indonesian citizens and global learners

items.title: Inquiry-Based and Student-Centered
points: Active learning, critical thinking, problem-solving emphasized
Differentiation for diverse learners (EAL, SEN, gifted)

items.title: Balanced
points: Academic rigor balanced with wellbeing and character development
Breadth (exposure to multiple disciplines) and depth (mastery of core subjects)
Time for co-curricular activities, creativity, and rest

content.text: Eduversal Partner Schools follow the Cambridge International Education pathway, which spans ages 5-19 and aligns with international best practices.

items: Sanford Harmony program integrated into Cambridge Personal, Social & Emotional Development curriculum

Supports Profil Pelajar Pancasila competencies from early years

Cross-curricular themes (e.g., environment, health, citizenship)

Summative: School-based tests aligned to Cambridge objectives
External diagnostic tests in English, Mathematics, and Science

Not high-stakes; informs transition to Lower Secondary

content.text: Legal Requirement: All schools in Indonesia, including Cambridge schools, must deliver mandatory national subjects and fulfill Ministry of Education curriculum standards (Section 2.4).

content.title: 1. Pendidikan Pancasila dan Kewarganegaraan (PPKn) - Civics Education
Purpose
content.text: Instill Indonesian national identity, civic values, and understanding of Pancasila (the five founding principles of Indonesia).

content.title: Pancasila Principles
items: Belief in One God (Ketuhanan Yang Maha Esa)
Just and Civilized Humanity (Kemanusiaan yang Adil dan Beradab)
Unity of Indonesia (Persatuan Indonesia)
Democracy Guided by Wisdom (Kerakyatan yang Dipimpin oleh Hikmat Kebijaksanaan)
Social Justice (Keadilan Sosial)
Constitution and Governance: Indonesian governmental structure, rights and responsibilities of citizens
National Symbols: Flag, anthem, coat of arms, national holidays
Social and Moral Issues: Anti-corruption, tolerance, community service
Language of Instruction: Bahasa Indonesia
Periods per Week: 2 hours (Grades 1-12)
Teacher Qualification: Indonesian-certified PPKn teacher or social studies teacher with PPKn training
Assessment: School-based tests, projects, participation (not Cambridge-assessed)
Themes complement Cambridge Global Perspectives (citizenship, ethics, social issues)
Indonesian context enriches discussions in Cambridge History, Geography, Economics

content.title: Purpose
content.text: Develop proficiency in national language (reading, writing, speaking, listening), literature appreciation, and cultural literacy.

items: Language Skills: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, comprehension
Literature: Indonesian poetry, novels, short stories, drama (classic and contemporary authors)
Communication: Formal and informal registers, presentations, debates
Media Literacy: Analyzing texts, critical reading
Language of Instruction: Bahasa Indonesia
Periods per Week: 4-6 hours (varies by grade level)
Teacher Qualification: Indonesian-certified Bahasa Indonesia teacher
Assessment: School-based tests, essays, oral presentations, literature projects
All students graduate with strong Bahasa Indonesia literacy (equivalent to native speaker proficiency for Indonesian students; advanced proficiency for non-Indonesian students)
Supports university admission in Indonesia (Bahasa Indonesia required for national exams or admission tests)
Students develop biliteracy (English via Cambridge, Indonesian via national curriculum)
Translation and comparative literature projects bridge both languages

content.title: Purpose
content.text: Provide religious instruction aligned with student's faith, promoting moral values and spiritual development.

items: Islam: Quran, Hadith, Islamic history, fiqh (jurisprudence), akhlaq (ethics)
Christianity (Protestant/Catholic): Bible study, Christian theology, church history, ethics
Hinduism: Vedas, Bhagavad Gita, Hindu philosophy, rituals
Buddhism: Tripitaka, Buddhist teachings, meditation, ethics
Confucianism: Confucian classics, ethics, family values
Other: If student practices different faith, alternative arrangement made (study independently or receive instruction from community religious leader)
Language of Instruction: Bahasa Indonesia (or language of religious texts with translation)
Periods per Week: 2-3 hours (Grades 1-12)
Teacher Qualification: Religious education teacher certified in respective faith
Grouping: Students grouped by religion for instruction (separate classes for Islam, Christianity, Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism)
Assessment: School-based tests, projects, memorization (e.g., Quranic verses for Muslim students), ethical reflection
School provides qualified teachers for all faiths represented in student body
Prayer spaces available (e.g., musholla for Muslim students, chapel or quiet room for Christian students)
Religious observances accommodated (e.g., time for Friday prayers, fasting during Ramadan)
Ethical discussions in Cambridge subjects (Philosophy, Global Perspectives, Literature) informed by diverse religious perspectives
Respectful dialogue and interfaith understanding emphasized

Regional History (e.g., Jakarta history and development)

Assessment: School-based; often project-based or performance-based (e.g., cultural presentation, craft creation)

content.title: National Curriculum Standards by Grade Level
content.text: Indonesian Ministry of Education (Kemendikbudristek) specifies minimum content standards and learning objectives for each national subject at each grade level, detailed in:

items: Kurikulum Nasional (Merdeka) (current framework as of 2024-2025)
Capaian Pembelajaran (CP) - Learning Outcomes for each subject and phase
Curriculum maps for national subjects aligned to CP
Lesson plans reference national standards
Assessment measures progress against CP
Documentation available for inspection (Dapodik, Dinas visits)

content.text: Purpose: Ensure comprehensive coverage of both the Cambridge and Indonesian curriculum requirements, with clear progression across grades.

content.title: What is a Curriculum Map?
content.text: A visual or tabular representation showing:

items: What is taught (topics, units, skills)
When it is taught (term, month, week)
How it aligns to standards (Cambridge objectives, Indonesian CP)
Why it matters (Schoolwide Learner Outcomes, Profil Pelajar Pancasila competencies)

content.title: Example: Grade 10 IGCSE Biology Curriculum Map (Excerpt)
content.text: Full Map:

items: Covers all units for the entire two-year IGCSE course (Grades 9-10)
Includes term breaks, mock exams, and revision periods
Shared with students at the start of the course (transparency)

content.text: Scope: What content is covered across the curriculum (breadth)
Sequence: The order in which content is taught (progression)

items: Ensure no gaps or redundant overlap
Show vertical alignment (Grade 7 Math builds on Grade 6; Grade 10 Chemistry builds on Grade 9 Science)
Facilitate teacher transitions (new teacher can see where the previous teacher left off)
Subject-specific document (e.g., "Mathematics Scope & Sequence Grades 1-12")
Grade-by-grade breakdown of topics
Spiral curriculum approach: Topics revisited with increasing depth (e.g., fractions in Grade 3, 5, 7, 9 - each time more complex)
Algebra builds from simple expressions (Grade 7) → equations (Grade 8) → quadratics (Grade 9) → advanced algebra (Grade 10-11)
Geometry progresses from basic shapes → advanced properties → trigonometry

content.title: Integration: Cambridge + National Subjects in Weekly Timetable
content.text: Example: Grade 10 Weekly Timetable (40 periods @ 45 minutes each) (Demo Only)

items: Cambridge subjects = 27 periods (66%)
National subjects = 10 periods (24%)
P5 & PE = 4 periods (10%)
Balanced but Cambridge-focused (prepares for IGCSE exams while fulfilling Indonesian requirements)

items: End of each academic year (May-June)

content.title: Integration Across All Subjects
content.text: Projects (Section 2.4) are inherently interdisciplinary, involving multiple subjects and real-world issues.

content.title: Example Profile Pelajar Pancasila Project: "Sustainable Living" (Grade 9, Term 1)

content.text: Driving Question: "How can our school community reduce environmental impact and promote sustainability?"

items: Science: Investigate carbon footprint, waste management, renewable energy
Math: Calculate school's energy usage, cost-benefit analysis of solar panels
Geography: Study climate change and local environmental issues
PPKn: Explore government policies on environment, civic responsibility
Bahasa Indonesia: Write public awareness campaign materials
Art: Design posters and infographics for campaign
ICT: Create website or video documentary

content.title: Timeline
content.text: 4 weeks (block schedule: 2-3 hours per week dedicated to project)

items: Students develop action plan (e.g., start recycling program, reduce plastic use, organize tree planting)
Implement one initiative in school
Document and reflect on learning
Profil Pelajar Pancasila competencies (not subject grades): Bernalar Kritis, Kreatif, Bergotong Royong, Berkebinekaan Global
Rubric assesses process (research, collaboration, creativity) and product (quality of action plan, impact)

subsections.title: English as an Additional Language Integration

content.text: Challenge: Many Indonesian students enter Eduversal schools with limited English proficiency but must access rigorous Cambridge curriculum taught in English.
Solution: Comprehensive EAL support model integrated into curriculum.

content.title: EAL Proficiency Framework
content.text: Eduversal adopts CEFR (Common European Framework of Reference) or WIDA (World-Class Instructional Design and Assessment) framework for EAL proficiency levels:

items: A1 (Beginner): Basic phrases, simple sentences
A2 (Elementary): Simple conversations on familiar topics
B1 (Intermediate): Understand main points of clear standard input, can describe experiences
B2 (Upper Intermediate): Interact with fluency, understand complex texts
C1 (Advanced): Fluent and spontaneous, understands demanding texts
C2 (Proficiency): Near-native; can understand virtually everything
Students should reach B2 minimum by end of Grade 10 (ready for IGCSE)
C1 by end of Grade 11 (ready for AS/A Level)

content.title: Pull-Out EAL (Beginner - A1/A2)
items: Students with lowest English proficiency pulled out of some Cambridge subject lessons for intensive English instruction
Focus: Survival English, basic academic vocabulary, foundational grammar
Gradual transition to mainstream as proficiency improves

content.title: Push-In EAL (Intermediate - B1/B2)
items: EAL specialist co-teaches with subject teacher in mainstream classroom
Provides scaffolding (simplified instructions, visual aids, sentence frames)
Pre-teaches vocabulary before units
Small group support during lessons

content.title: Sheltered Instruction (All Levels)
items: Subject teachers trained in EAL pedagogy
Use strategies to make content accessible:
Visual supports: Diagrams, videos, graphic organizers
Simplified language: Chunk instructions, use clear sentence structures
Collaborative learning: Pair EAL students with proficient English speakers
Differentiated tasks: Provide options for different language levels (e.g., write paragraph vs. create labeled diagram)

content.title: Academic Language Development
items: Explicit teaching of academic vocabulary and discourse (e.g., compare/contrast, analyze, hypothesize)
Genre-based writing instruction (lab reports, essays, persuasive writing)
Reading strategies (skimming, scanning, annotation)
EAL proficiency assessed termly using standardized tools (e.g., WIDA ACCESS, Cambridge English Placement Test)
Progress tracked in student language profile
Student reaches B2 level (CEFR) or WIDA Level 4-5
Can access grade-level Cambridge curriculum with minimal support
Continues to receive accommodations as needed (e.g., extended time, word bank) but no longer pulled out
EAL student profiles with proficiency levels and progress
EAL support schedules (pull-out, push-in)
Teacher training records (sheltered instruction, EAL strategies)
Student work samples showing language development

content.text: Principle: All students can learn and achieve high standards, but they need different pathways and supports.

content.title: Content Differentiation (What Students Learn)
items: Readiness-based: Adjust complexity (e.g., Grade 9 Math Extended vs. Core tier)
Interest-based: Offer choice in project topics (e.g., research essay on any aspect of WW2)
Learning profile: Provide materials in multiple formats (text, video, audio, hands-on)

content.title: Process Differentiation (How Students Learn)
items: Flexible grouping: Pair/group students strategically (mixed ability, similar ability, interest-based) depending on the task
Scaffolding: Provide graphic organizers, sentence starters, and step-by-step guides for students who need structure
Tiered activities: Same objective, different difficulty levels (e.g., all students analyze poem, but questions range from literal comprehension to thematic analysis)

content.title: Product Differentiation (How Students Demonstrate Learning)
items: Choice boards: Students select from menu of assessment options (essay, presentation, video, poster, model)
Varied criteria: Rubrics with multiple pathways to success (e.g., creativity, accuracy, depth students excel in different areas)

content.title: Support for Students with Special Educational Needs (SEN)

items: Screening at admission (learning assessments, parent questionnaire)
Teacher referral if concerns arise
Diagnostic assessment by a school psychologist or an external specialist

content.title: Individualized Education Plan (IEP) or Individualized Learning Plan (ILP)

items: Document student's strengths, needs, and goals
Specify accommodations and modifications
Reviewed termly with parents, students, and teachers
Extended time on tests
Preferential seating (front of class, away from distractions)
Note-taking support (copy of teacher's notes, peer buddy)
Assistive technology (text-to-speech software, graphic organizers)
Chunked assignments (break long tasks into smaller steps)
Reduced workload (fewer problems, shorter essay)
Simplified texts or alternate materials
Adjusted grading criteria (focus on key objectives, not all)
SEN students remain in mainstream classes with support (inclusion model)
Pull-out for specialized intervention only when necessary (e.g., reading remediation, speech therapy)
SEN register (list of students with identified needs)
IEPs/ILPs (individualized plans)
Progress monitoring data
Accommodation implementation logs (which accommodations used, effectiveness)

content.title: Challenge and Enrichment for Gifted/High-Achieving Students

items: High performance on standardized tests (Checkpoint, EASE)
Teacher nomination based on classroom excellence
Student/parent request

content.title: Curriculum Compacting
items: Pre-assess students; if already mastered content, allow to skip and work on extension activities
Example: Student tests out of Grade 10 Math review unit, uses time for enrichment (exploring advanced topics, independent project)

content.title: Acceleration
items: Subject-specific acceleration (e.g., Grade 9 student takes Grade 10 Math)
Early IGCSE entry (take some IGCSEs in Grade 10 instead of Grade 11)

content.title: Enrichment
items: Depth over breadth (explore topics in greater complexity)
Independent study projects
Mentorship with teacher or external expert

content.title: Competitions and EduOS
items: Science Olympiads (Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Math)
EduOS camps for intensive preparation (Section 3, Section 19)
Gifted/talented student register
Compacting and enrichment plans
Competition participation and results

subsections.title: Use of Technology and Blended Learning

content.text: Purpose: Enhance learning through strategic use of digital tools, while maintaining strong pedagogy and human connection.

items: Primary (Grades 1-6): Shared devices (computer lab, tablet cart) for specific activities
Secondary (Grades 7-12): Students may use personal devices (BYOD - Bring Your Own Device) or school-provided laptops/tablets
School provides: Interactive Flat Panels (IFP) or projectors in all classrooms, reliable internet
EduNav: School information system for grades, attendance, communication, and assignments
Learning Management System (LMS): Google Classroom, Microsoft Teams, or Moodle for posting assignments, resources, and discussions
Assessment Tools: Online quizzes (Kahoot, Quizizz, Google Forms), EASE platform
Communication: Email, messaging apps (for parent-school communication)

content.title: Flipped Classroom
items: At Home: Students watch instructional videos or read materials (introduction to new concept)
In Class: Active learning activities (problem-solving, discussions, labs, projects) with teacher support
Example: Grade 11 Physics students watch a video on Newton's Laws at home; in class, conduct experiments and solve complex problems collaboratively

content.title: Station Rotation
items: Setup: Multiple learning stations in classroom (teacher-led, collaborative, technology-based, independent)
Process: Students rotate through stations in timed intervals
Example: Grade 8 English - Station 1: Teacher works with small group on essay structure; Station 2: Peer editing pairs; Station 3: Vocabulary practice on tablets; Station 4: Independent reading

content.title: Hybrid/Flex Learning
items: Combination: Mix of face-to-face and online learning (especially useful for exam prep, remediation, or when student absent)
Example: Grade 12 AS Level students attend 3 in-person classes and 1 online asynchronous lesson per week (online: watch recorded lecture, complete practice problems; submit for feedback)

content.title: Remote Learning Contingency
items: Preparedness: All teachers trained to deliver online lessons if campus closure required (health emergency, natural disaster)
Continuity: Curriculum continues via video conferencing (Zoom, Google Meet), LMS, digital resources
Equity: School provides device loan and internet data support for students lacking access
Students and parents sign AUP at enrollment
Rules for device use, internet access, digital citizenship
Consequences for misuse (cyberbullying, accessing inappropriate content, cheating)
Integrated into ICT, Global Perspectives, and homeroom lessons
Topics: Online safety, privacy, respectful communication, evaluating sources, plagiarism avoidance
Guidelines on ethical use of AI tools (e.g., ChatGPT, Grammarly)
Permitted: Brainstorming, editing, grammar check
Prohibited: Submitting AI-generated work as own without attribution; using AI to write entire essays or solve problems meant to assess student's understanding
Teachers design assessments less susceptible to AI misuse (process-oriented, oral presentations, in-class writing)
AUP signed forms
Digital citizenship lesson plans
AI usage guidelines (published in student handbook)
Technology integration examples in lesson plans

content.title: EduOS (Eduversal Olimpiade Sains) - Specialized Olympiad Preparation
Purpose
content.text: Intensive coaching for students competing in national and international science Olympiads (Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Mathematics, Astronomy, Earth Science).

content.text: Note: EduOS is a separate program from the Eduversal Quality Management System (QMS). content.title: What is Universal Design for Learning?
content.text: Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is a research-based framework for curriculum design that provides all students with equal opportunities to learn. Rooted in neuroscience and educational psychology, UDL recognizes that learners differ in how they perceive, comprehend, engage with, and express their understanding of information. Rather than retrofitting curriculum for individual students after challenges arise, UDL proactively designs flexible learning experiences that accommodate diverse learning needs from the outset.

Core Philosophy: UDL shifts the mindset from "What's wrong with this student?" to "What's wrong with this curriculum?" When barriers exist, UDL asks educators to remove obstacles in the curriculum design rather than expecting students to overcome fixed barriers through sheer effort or remediation.

items: Multiple Means of Representation (the "what" of learning): Present information in varied formats
Multiple Means of Action & Expression (the "how" of learning): Provide options for students to demonstrate knowledge
Multiple Means of Engagement (the "why" of learning): Stimulate interest and motivation through choice and relevance

content.title: Why UDL Matters for Eduversal Partner Schools
Supports Cambridge Rigour with Inclusive Access
items: Cambridge International Education emphasizes high academic standards and the development of transferable skills (critical thinking, problem-solving, communication). UDL ensures that all students--regardless of their starting point--can access these challenging curricula without lowering expectations. By designing lessons with built-in flexibility, teachers maintain rigour while removing barriers that prevent students from demonstrating their true capabilities.

content.title: Aligns with Indonesian Inclusion Requirements
items: Indonesia's national education framework (Kurikulum Merdeka) and Profil Pelajar Pancasila emphasize inclusive education and recognizing students' diverse potentials. UDL operationalizes these principles by ensuring that curriculum design honours kebinekaan (diversity) and supports all learners, including those with special educational needs (SEN), English as an Additional Language (EAL) learners, and students from varied socio-economic backgrounds.

content.title: Enhances Differentiation Already in Practice
items: As outlined in Section 5.9, Eduversal schools already implement differentiation strategies. UDL provides a systematic framework that makes differentiation more proactive, sustainable, and embedded in curriculum design rather than reactive accommodations made on-the-fly. While differentiation often focuses on modifying instruction for individual students, UDL builds flexibility into the curriculum from the start, reducing the need for constant adaptations.

content.title: Addresses the Needs of EAL Learners
items: With 40-70% of students in Eduversal schools being EAL learners (Section 5.8), UDL strategies--such as providing visual supports, offering multiple ways to express understanding, and scaffolding language--are essential for linguistic and academic access. UDL and the EAL framework work synergistically to support language development while ensuring content mastery.

content.title: Prepares for CIS/WASC Accreditation
items: UDL demonstrates the school's commitment to inclusive practices, responsive curriculum design, and evidence-based pedagogy--all of which are valued by CIS (Council of International Schools) and WASC (Western Association of Schools and Colleges) accreditors. UDL artifacts (planning templates, student work samples, curriculum audits) serve as compelling evidence of teaching and learning excellence.
